title: Stubborn Heart
label: One Little Indian
description: The London synth-pop duo first gained notice when they surreptitiously slipped their first 12" into a few of the city's record shops. On their debut album, singer Luca Santucci obsesses over a failed relationship and other romantic traumas.

title: Turns Turns Turns EP
label: Arbutus
description: This Grimes-associated Montreal duo's confident, decluttered new EP finds them taking a sharp turn from their murky debut. But listen closely, and you'll hear the personal, internal, dreamy echoes of their past.

title: Grace/Confusion
label: Carpark
description: Last year Dayve Hawk hinted that his third album as Memory Tapes might contain Black Sabbath-worthy dirges. That's miles away from the liquefied pop Grace/Confusion delivers.

title: Greatest of Deceivers
label: Indie
description: Featuring past and present members of Mayhem, Gorgoroth, 1349, DHG, and God Seed, the Norwegian black metal band's fourth album is anything but orthodox.

title: Roomful of Teeth
label: New Amsterdam
description: Vocal octet Roomful of Teeth is interested in the places where the human voice is stretched to extremes: Intuit throat singing, Korean p'ansori, yodeling, all of which and more can be found on their self-titled, Kickstarter-financed debut.

title: Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness
label: EMI
description: Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness was one of the most generous records of the 90s. Smashing Pumpkins took it upon themselves to make a record that only teenagers could love and for many it was the only one they needed. This mega-deluxe box set pads the original with an additional 64 tracks.

title: Night Has a Thousand Screams
label: Rock Action
description: Earlier this year, the Kansas City electronic musician Matt Hill performed to a screening of the 1982 serial killer slasher film Pieces at the Glasgow Music and Film Festival. Mogwai's Stuart Braithwaite was in attendance and offered to release the music on his Rock Action imprint.

title: Wu-Block
label: E1
description: This collaborative album between Ghostface Killah and D-Block's Sheek Louch features spots from Raekwon, Method Man, Jadakiss, Styles P, Masta Killa, GZA, and Erykah Badu, among others. Everyone sounds engaged and happy to be in the room.

title: Girl on Fire
label: RCA
description: Alicia Keys' fifth studio album, a collection about rebirth and renewal, features production from Jamie xx, Swizz Beatz, and Dr. Dre and guest spots from Nicki Minaj, Maxwell, and Bruno Mars.

title: Turn on the Bright Lights: The Tenth Anniversary Edition
label: Matador
description: Interpol's 2002 full-length debut is given a stellar 10th Anniversary reissue complete with demos and B-sides. All told, it makes it unequivocally clear that Turn on the Bright Lights is the sum of its players, not its influences.

title: Widowmaker
label: Prosthetic
description: The outspoken British metal quartet appear uniformly in balaclavas and turn their backs to the audience in a live setting. Their second album, a three-part suite, cycles through 40 minutes of doom, thrash, noise, somber Godspeed violin, serial killer samples, and drone.

title: On Triple Beams
label: In the Red
description: On their third album, Tyvek's delivering a unifying garage-rock anthem for Detroit's punks, nerds, and audiophiles fighting for something to do on a Saturday night.

title: Bish Bosch
label: 4AD
description: Scott Walker's third album in the last 17 years features drums and guitars and other passing references to rock music, but its deepest roots are in the dissonant, turn-of-the century compositions by Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Webern, and Berg.

title: The Allah-Las
label: Innovative Leisure
description: On their self-titled debut, the melancholic Los Angeles garage rock band obsessively construct jangly, seemingly simple mid-tempo pop songs in the studio like they're building grand pocket symphonies.

title: The Crystal Ark
label: DFA
description: Longtime DFA associate Gavin Russom returns with a full-length from his project with vocalist and visual artist Viva Ruiz.

title: From the Vaults, Vol. 1
label: Season of Mist
description: From the Vaults, Vol. 1 collects unreleased and rare songs recorded by Kylesa between 2005 and 2012, but nothing here sounds like it was readymade for an ephemera stockpile. The dozen tracks are every bit as crafted as those on the Savannah band's excellent studio albums.

title: Instrumental Tourist
label: Software
description: Electronic composers Tim Hecker and Daniel Lopatin (Oneohtrix Point Never) each have their own clearly defined aesthetic. Their collaborative album, which they created in real time, is an easy listen loaded with a billowy atmosphere and discernible melody.

title: Blue Lines
label: EMI
description: Listening to the remastered box set of Massive Attacks's debut album 21 years after its initial release is like reading an old William Gibson novel that describes the then-near future, which is now the present, with unsettling precision.

title: Dagdrøm
label: Broken Spine
description: The smoggy haze of fuzz and scuzz that permeates the Berlin-based doom-gaze duo's albums is so relentless and all-consuming that it starts to feel as comforting and commonplace as oxygen. Though by Nadja's standards, Dagdrøm starts off unusually serene.

title: Drones
label: Bedroom Community
description: Nico Muhly's Drones, initially spread across three EPs and collected here as a full-length, toys with the notion of drone in a way that fits the indie-classical composer's "cat meets yarn ball" sensibility.

title: Ex-Cult
label: Goner
description: Sharing members with indie-popsters Magic Kids, the Memphis garage rock band formerly known as Sex Cult showcase a great sense of punk's past on their Ty Segall-produced debut.

title: Mirror Maru
label: Pelican Fly
description: The young Norwegian producer first turned heads with remixes of Lana Del Rey, Drake, and Jeremih and a spot on Rustie's Essential Mix. Blending technical sensibility with pop playfulness, his debut EP communicates a fully realized artistic persona.

title: More for the Masses
label: HoZac
description: On their 2010 debut LP, the Lansing, Mich., garage rock band proved they were good at crafting psychedelic songs in the vein of the Seeds. With their sophomore collection, they bust out a new set of tricks.

title: Sushi
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: Relatively concept free, James Ferraro's follow up to last year's much discussed Far Side Virtual features well-made electronic instrumental music, the best of which rivals that of any current producer. What makes it engaging is its playfulness.

title: A Wrenched Virile Lore
label: Sub Pop
description: Almost 15 years after Kicking a Dead Pig comes Mogwai's second remix album, featuring Jesu/Godflesh's Justin K. Broadrick, Tim Hecker, the Soft Moon, and others taking on tracks from the 2011 LP Hardcore Will Never Die But You Will.

title: True
label: Terrible
description: After a few false starts, Solange Knowles comes into her own with songwriting and production assistance from Devonté Hynes. True marks the sound of a singer hitting a graceful stride, in her own time and on her own terms.

title: A World Out Of Time
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On their second full-length of 2012, the Portland psych rock band took a less long-form approach than usual. A World Out of Time is Eternal Tapestry's most collage-oriented release, offering varied sounds fused with hard cuts, cross-fades, and outdoorsy ambiance.

title: Jummy
label: Fourth Wave
description: The 20-year old British art-house producer's debut reveals a dedication to haze and clutter mostly absent on his early singles. Mixing big, wet drum sounds with short, cloudy bursts of piano and mumbled half-syllables, Jummy refuses to fade into the background.

title: Black Pleasure
label: Mishka
description: On the follow-up to 2011's Digital Lows, Memphis rapper Cities Aviv submerges his natural tendencies beneath a strong post-punk influence, making for a bold collection that works with regard to his wordplay, but not always on the production.

title: Unapologetic
label: Def Jam
description: Rihanna's seventh album is designed to engage with our perception of Rihanna the Pop Star and Rihanna the Victim. The source of its fascination is the dissonance between the two but its failures are more pedestrian.

title: OFF/ON
label: Spectrum Spools
description: A year after their dreamy self-titled debut, the Brooklyn analog synth trio put a darker spin on their sound. At its core, OFF/ON is a record that thrives on possibility and hedged optimism.

title: Quarter Turns Over a Living Line
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: A cold ripple of alienation and abandon pulses through the work of this London-based production duo. At times Raime's debut album feels like a logical endpoint for dubstep, a natural dead zone where rumination can come to an uneasy rest.

title: Wiki93 EP
label: XL
description: Led by the nimble 18-year-old rapper Wiki, the N.Y. four-piece come from a hardcore background and are aesthetically guided by early-90s New York hip hop. Their debut EP for XL is mostly a case of untapped potential.

title: Reloaded
label: Decon
description: The Long Island rapper's quotable second album features production work from the Alchemist and Q-Tip and improves on his 2010 debut in every conceivable way.

title: Chocomel Daze (Live 1987)
label: Merge
description: Recorded before a small crowd in the Dutch town of Nijmegen, Chocomel Daze captures the original (and now reunited) Dinosaur Jr. lineup trio touring behind their heaviest, most incendiary album, 1987's You're Living All Over Me.

title: We Don't Even Live Here
label: Rhymesayers
description: Stefon Alexander's fourth LP of clenched-fist, politicized, and proudly Midwestern hip-hop features production from Lazerbeak and Boys Noize, along with a Justin Vernon cameo.

title: Jessica Pratt
label: Birth
description: San Francisco's Jessica Pratt is a young songwriter with a decidedly old soul and a voice that balances spry sweetness with husky grit. Her songs feel lodged in some liminal realm between past and present, devoid of references that might place them in a historical moment.

title: Movement
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Using her crystalline voice as a chief input for her laptop, the Calif.-based composer arrives at a poignant nexus of electronic accessibility and experimentation. Her impressive debut owes as much to her academic forebears as her club contemporaries.

title: The Velvet Underground & Nico
label: Polydor
description: This limited six-disc set of the 1967 classic includes remasters, alternate versions and mixes, practice sessions recorded at Andy Warhol's Factory, a live recording, and a remaster of Nico's Chelsea Girl, on which the Velvets performed.

title: Sequitur
label: Kranky
description: Emeralds member Steve Hauschildt has said his second album for Kranky in two years uses technology as a way of expressing androgyny. He moves into intellectual electronics without losing the playfulness that initially made his work appealing.

title: Pale Fire
label: Control Group
description: Sarah Assbring has said her fifth El Perro del Mar album, the first since 2009's Love Is Not Pop, was inspired by the 90s house and trip hop she used to love. She goes so far as to include a very noticeable sample from Massive Attack's "Unfinished Sympathy".

title: The Odds
label: Dischord
description: Ian MacKaye and Amy Farina's four-year-old son appears on the cover of their third album as the Evens, their first in six years. A powerful example of aging gracefully, The Odds is the product of scaling down operations rather than of giving up or throwing the fans a nostalgia trip.

title: The Disintegration Loops
label: Temporary Residence
description: The four volumes of William Basinski's ambient masterpiece have been gathered into a gorgeous and impressive  9xLP, 5xCD box set, including two previously unreleased live performances.

title: Go Easy
label: Siltbreeze
description: The Australian rock quartet, which features three siblings and "a spiritual brother," are still unruly, but everything fits together on Go Easy, their most coherent album to date. The record evokes the way mid-90s Royal Trux made rock sound primitive while still mining its history.

title: Growing Seeds
label: Sacred Bones
description: Swedish electronic musician and singer Hannes Norrvide's dark post-punk minimal wave has the obsessive feel of something banged out in one demented trance. His debut, Growing Seeds, hits the same nagging sweet spot as the most hypnotically driving 8-bit music.

title: Relief
label: Editions Mego
description: Relief, a single 36-minute song that wrestles hectic squirming into an impregnable monument, may be Chicago noise artist Kevin Drumm's next milestone. Even during its most violent passages, it's more entrancing than overwhelming.

title: Cosmic Angel: The Illuminati Prince/ss
label: UNO
description: Following a sinister, hallucinatory handful of one-off tracks, the charismatic N.Y. poet and performance artist Michael Quattlebaum's first Mykki Blanco full-length is a grab-bag of experimentation tailored to 2012's increasingly blurry rap landscape.

title: King Animal
label: Republic
description: The mega-selling grunge band's recent reunion has a par-for-the-course, procedural air: Soundgarden are back together and making new music because, well, that's what dormant alt-rock institutions are supposed to do now, right?

title: Lonely at the Top
label: Werkdiscs
description: The producer Luke Blair began his fourth and best album after finding a bag of tapes near his London home. Rather than becoming a found sound library, the tapes were a catalyst: Lonely at the Top carves sound into shapes that spell out emotions too tricky for words.

title: Diamond In The Ruff
label: Babygrande
description: Ever since detaching from Roc-A-Fella, the Philadelphia rapper has felt a bit like a town crier with no square. On his fourth album, his first for Babygrande, he positions himself as a reliable alternative to the mainstream.

title: Our House on the Hill
label: Woodsist
description: The second album from Woods bassist Kevin Morby's band with Vivian Girls frontwoman Cassie Ramone finds them adding country inflections. It's a step up from their debut, with clearer production that better showcases Morby's introspective lyrics.

title: Temporal
label: Ipecac
description: Spanning Isis' 13-year career, this 2xCD and DVD package combines a handful of unreleased rehearsal and alternate takes with Black Sabbath and Godflesh covers and other songs the expansive metal band routed to limited-edition releases instead of their proper records.

title: Nebula Dance
label: Planet Mu
description: Brighton producer Alan Myson is often referred to as a dubstep musician, but his stylistic slipperiness has reached a peak on his impressive third full-length. The collection resembles a broad survey of the cerebral, less hedonistic corners of the dance music world circa 2012.

title: The MOEna Lisa
label: SWTBRDS
description: The Bay Area rapper has positioned his new mixtape, featuring Freddie Gibbs and Main Attrakionz, as the third installment of a gentrification-themed trilogy he began in 2010. Like Gibbs, he treats "gangsta music" as something to present and then to get out of the way of.

title: Put Your Sad Down EP
label: Vagrant
description: This tour EP finds the Brooklyn new age pop duo of vocalist Alejandra Deheza and multi-instrumentalist Ben Curtis covering Silver Apples alongside four new tracks, including their most outlandish material to date.

title: A List of the Burning Mountains
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The Brooklyn band's newest is a vinyl-only LP consisting of two side-long tracks, both sharing a name with the album. It sounds uncalculated and uncontrived, as if Oneida's playing whatever they feel like playing at the moment.

title: Silver & Gold
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Sufjan's follow-up to 2006's Songs for Christmas set stretches 59 tracks across nearly three hours. It's an obsessive excavation into his conflicted Christmas heart, complete with a fold-it-yourself paper star ornament, stickers, temporary tattoos, a poster, and an 80-page booklet.

title: Pro Style EP
label: Type
description: On this three-song EP, the onetime Yellow Swan continues the noisy take on EDM he explored on his 2011 LP, Man With Potential. It's a hectic maelstrom you can imagine pounding through a sweaty club late at night.

title: Power and Passion
label: Interscope
description: Exquire's first major label offering consists of a direct reiteration of the science fiction-loving, depressive, addictive persona offered on last year's Lost in Translation. It's a vulgar, dissonant listen, assisted by fantastic Def Jux style beats from the likes of El-P and Harry Fraud.

title: Dream On
label: Planet Mu
description: Brooklyn-based producer (and Mi Ami member) Daniel Martin-McCormick's second Ital album of 2012 exploits the fine line between repetition as groove and repetition as unnerving tic. Dream On is head music that worries the body.

title: Trilogy
label: Universal Republic
description: This set gathers the three 2011 mixtapes from Toronto R&B singer Abel Tefsaye and adds three new songs along with new mixes and mastering. Trilogy as a whole sets up a narrative that was previously only implied and has more force when heard in this form.

title: Work Hard, Play Hard, Pray Hard: Hard Time, Good Time & End Time Music, 1923-1936
label: Tompkins Square
description: This collection gathers 42 folk and country songs recorded between 1923 and 1936 and places them on three CDs, "Work Hard," "Play Hard," and "Pray Hard." The bulk of the material was salvaged by guitarist Nathan Salsburg from 78"'s found in a dumpster outside an old Kentucky man's home.

title: At the Down-turned Jagged Rim of the Sky
label: Kranky
description: The Toledo slowcore artist Jessica Bailiff's new solo album, her first since 2006, is suffused with her familiar cool, half-chanted singing and plenty of sonic murk. But it's also quite unlike anything she's done before.

title: The Bears for Lunch
label: Guided By Voices, Inc.
description: The reunited Guided by Voices' third 2012 release is the most consistent of the lot, faithfully approximating the tumbling, track-to-track momentum of the band's mid-90s masterworks, proving that Pollard and co are determined to make the most of this second wind.

title: (III)
label: Fiction
description: Crystal Castles songs could once be split into two camps, the "pretty" ones and the "aggressive" ones. (III) is by a large margin the most focused record by the band, and frontwman Alice Glass' lyrics take on a new importance.

title: Alone Together
label: Stones Throw
description: The Stones Throw drummer/producer has worked with everyone from Paul McCartney to Common and tours with Diana Krall. His first solo offering is a grand addition to the ever-expanding canon of instrumental hip-hop beat tapes.

title: Information Age
label: Krian
description: The Brooklyn hip-hop duo Dead Prez have remained radical and unpredictable for over a decade. On their new studio album Information Age, Stic.man and M-1 scrap every compelling element of their music and go full Enya.

title: Lights Out
label: Nuclear Blast
description: The 70s-leaning Swedish band Graveyard point to a tradition of American blues and European blues rock that's always been part of metal's family tree, no matter the latest fashion. On their third album, they mix catchy, hyperkinetic songs with slowly swelling ballads.

title: Top 10 Hits of the End of the World
label: Paw Tracks
description: Sisters Taraka and Nimai Larson anchor the new-age revival project Prince Rama. On their new album, their best to date, they "invented 10 different pop bands that died during the apocalypse, channeling the ghosts of each one to perform the various songs."

title: The Studio Albums 1968-1979
label: Rhino
description: The brilliant singer-songwriter's first 10 studio albums, cut during an 11-year span, have been gathered in this import box set. During this run, Mitchell charted one of the most solid career arcs in contemporary music that then detoured into one of the strangest.

title: Vanitas
label: Candlelight
description: Anaal Nathrakh's albums are labyrinths of hyperactivity and idiosyncrasy. Challenging and evocative, the industrial-tinged British grindcore band's latest album is a thrill ride of horrors and unexpected hooks.

title: Release
label: Hessle
description: Since 2007, Kevin McAuley has run the scene-defining UK label Hessle with Pearson Sound and Ben UFO. This "double EP," McAuley's most substantial Pangea offering to date, is a wily, undefinable example of progressive underground dance music.

title: Ark
label: No Pain in Pop
description: The 21-year-old electro-acoustic composer and singer Sam Howard's debut LP focuses on "themes of isolation and death." Featuring live instruments and samples recorded at London-area churches and conservatories, it's an impressive leap from his two previous EPs.

title: Smalhans
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Following the dense Six Cups of Rebel, Hans-Peter Lindstrøm's second album of 2012 offers a no-frills version of what the Norwegian producer does best: endlessly spiraling, cosmic dance music.

title: Desert Strike EP
label: Fade to Mind
description: Fatima Al Qadiri, who has recorded under her own name and as Ayshay, returns with a strangely beautiful album that is hard to classify. The music references her childhood in Kuwait and the first Gulf War, but through a synthetic lens inspired in part by video games.

title: The Vermilion Border
label: Rough Trade
description: The Slits guitarist, who didn't play for years until the legendary punk band's mid-aughts reunion, releases her first solo full-length. At times it recalls Marianne Faithfull's mid-career, middle-age masterpiece Broken English.

title: Rave Age
label: Different
description: Rave Age sees French producer Pascal Arbez returning to maximalism in a timely fashion. The album's title addresses youth culture's embrace of intense electronic music, while the singles here echo the audacious moments of 2005's OK Cowboy.

title: Trap God
label: self-released
description: Gucci Mane is conservative when it comes to change, and it takes a few spins through Trap God before the differences between it and past records come into focus. But once they do, they cohere into a portrait of an artist in the midst of an aesthetic metamorphosis.

title: Free Reign
label: Domino
description: The enigmatic Liverpool band returns with an album heavy on Suicide-like groove and open-ended jams. The choice of  Daniel Lopatin of Oneohtrix Point Never as mixer adds an additional element of experimentation.

title: Red Horse
label: No Sleep
description: Red Horse marks Early Graves' first output since their vocalist was killed in a tour van accident in 2010. Hardened and honed by years of DIY touring and big-name support gigs, the San Francisco punk-inflected metal band's songs ring true with pain and anger.

title: Black Prince Fury
label: Moshi Moshi
description: Anna Meredith has already been composer in residence at the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, and currently occupies the same position at the Royal Philharmonic Society. Black Prince Fury is her first solo EP; a visceral, rhythmic set that recalls Moondog's cross-genre miniatures.

title: WOW
label: Monkeytown
description: Throughout their 20-year career, the German duo have deftly mixed traditional instrumentation with electronic textures that range from warm to brittle and disjointed. On their second release of 2012, Mouse on Mars deconstruct wonky, oddball bass music.

title: Lux
label: Warp
description: Brian Eno's new solo album, first created for an art installation, consists of four tracks spread across 75 minutes. It suggests that there's a reason Eno's name has become synonymous with "ambient" and why his thoughts on the music remain the gold standard.

title: Lovelessness
label: Metal Blade
description: The Vancouver metal band Bison B.C.'s fourth album is a muscular and expansive piece of stoner metal that seeks to challenge the laid-back, sluggish nature of that term.

title: Behind the Mirror
label: FDH
description: The Chicago garage-rock band's second LP of 2012 shows a dramatic shift in tone from the bubblegum-via-psych melodies of their self-titled debut. On Behind the Mirror they aim for "darker" psych, music that favors minor-key organ lines over bright, jangling guitar.

title: Burning Daylight
label: Dais Records
description: Seattle metal musician-cum-neo-folk singer-songwriter T.J. Cowgill offers pitch-black narratives sung in a low, sinister croak. But for all of Burning Daylight's spooky white noise and echoing haunted-house vocals, he's a 50s nostalgist at heart.

title: Just to Feel Anything
label: Editions Mego
description: Two years after the excellent Does It Look Like I'm Here?, Emeralds have smoothed and streamlined their sound, delving into the soft shapes of new age, post-rock, and corporate music.

title: About To Die EP
label: Domino
description: Although half of the About to Die EP sounds like a testing ground for ideas that show up more substantively on Swing Lo Magellan, it's also a showcase for how well simplicity works in Dirty Projectors' music, the value of direct sentiment, and why they don't always need to try so hard.

title: People Get Ready
label: Brassland
description: People Get Ready call themselves an interdisciplinary band, accompanying their music with choreographed live dance performance. On their eponymous debut, they play jagged, melodic, technically accomplished indie rock that encourages all-limbs-no-hips movement.

title: Ritual of Passing
label: Profound Lore
description: The dark Portland punk/deathrock band's sophomore album is an astonishing progression from their 2011 debut. Like Swans and even Eyehategod before them, Atriarch have started to sound as tough as their themes suggest they might.

title: La-Di-Da Recordings
label: Kranky
description: Between 1990 and 1993, the little-known Bristol trio created melodic, ethereal, well-styled shoegaze. Kranky's bare-bones reissue does a fine job of maintaining the group's mystery in compiling a nine-song survey of its microscopic discography.

title: Zeros
label: Captured Tracks
description: Oakland multi-instrumentalist Luis Vasquez returns with another album of moody and atmospheric post-punk; all of Vasquez's material's been darkly enveloping and fuzzed-out, but with Zeros you can hear him projecting outward to an audience.

title: Order of Noise
label: Tri Angle
description: Vessel is one of many names used by Bristol-based "non-dance dance music" producer Seb Gainsborough. The series of 12"s he released over the past year didn't offer an indication of just how wide open his vision would become on this debut full-length.

title: Tinsel and Lights
label: Merge
description: Tracey Thorn is rarely given her due for her role as a maternal figure to contemporary indie pop. A holiday album that includes White Stripes, Sufjan Stevens, Low, and Stephin Merritt covers plus originals and traditional fare, offers an opportunity to acknowledge her influence.

title: Come Home to Mama
label: Cooperative
description: Martha Wainwright's third studio album was produced by Cibo Matto's Yuka Honda. Featuring guest spots from Sean Lennon, Wilco's Nels Cline, and Dirty Three's Jim White, it gets its title from the collection's centerpiece, the last song Wainwright's mother Kate McGarrigle wrote before dying of cancer.

title: Sorry to Bother You
label: Anti-
description: The Coup have always been a party band first and foremost, and Sorry to Bother You reaffirms their belief that the revolution, if there is going to be one, will start at the hips. On their sixth album, frontman Boots Riley sounds as nimble, funny, and wry as ever.

title: Hands of Glory
label: Mom & Pop
description: Andrew Bird follows March's poppy, elegant Break It Yourself with Hands of Glory, a set of rustic songs recorded during loose sessions at his western Illinois barn. Bird and his band cover country tunes, strip down their own originals, and explore weighty Biblical themes.

title: Eternal Champ
label: Fool's Gold
description: The second release in three months from Wavves' Nathan Williams and his brother Joel "Kynan" is altogether a more impressive and diverse endeavor than its enjoyable but slight predecessor.

title: Good Don't Sleep
label: R&S
description: On their debut full-length, the Manchester art pop band who've worked with Hudson Mohawke, Late of the Pier, and the electronic label R&S, create a sonic world of their own.

title: Mantasy
label: Kompakt
description: The appeal of the producer, DJ, and Kompakt co-owner's first full-length of new material in eight years largely comes from how self-contained each cut is. Whether it's a horror show theme, a nod to Jan Hammer, a bouquet of harp trills and birdsong, or a jazz workout, each song aims at a distinct idea.

title: Dreams and Nightmares
label: Maybach
description: Meek Mill's major label debut, featuring Drake, Rick Ross, Mary J. Blige, Nas, Trey Songz, Wale, and others, is an album that's distinct in voice and sound, one that plays to the Philadelphia rapper's strengths.

label: Captured Tracks
description: On his second release of 2012, the young singer-songwriter writes about life-- both the heavy moments and the mundane ones-- with economy and newfound grace. He has a knack for building songs where the realness of his subject matter lies just below the surface.

title: Explore
label: Carpark
description: The 19-year-old college student and occasional surfer Yoodoo Park's debut GRMLN EP collects seven short, melancholic guitar-pop tracks that flit in and out over the course of 15 breezy minutes.

title: Landing on a Hundred
label: Vibration Vineyard
description: Coming a decade after The Headphone Masterpiece, Cody ChesnuTT's sophomore collection is an apt reflection of an artist restarting after several years without sacrificing the eccentricity that initially made him such a compelling figure.

title: Prins Thomas 2
label: Full Pupp
description: On his second solo album, the Norwegian producer continues to explore foggy krautrock, hippie jazz, and space disco. But Prins Thomas II jettisons the debut's live drums and bass in favor of drum machines, synthesizers, and slow, worming dance grooves.

title: Bossalinis & Fooliyones
label: Young One
description: On the 70-minute proper proper full-length from cloud rap duo Main Attrakionz, a sound that seemed all but doomed to stagnate is brightened and reconfigured in appealing ways. Bossalinis & Fooliyones features 13 producers over 17 tracks, with guest spots from Gucci Mane, Davinci, and others.

title: Psychedelic Pill
label: Warner Bros.
description: Neil Young's first collection of new material with Crazy Horse since 2003's Greendale features enough life and fuck-you attitude to remind a listener that "it's better to burn out than to fade away" wasn't necessarily about dying young, so long as you avoided phoning it in.

title: Free Dimensional
label: Astralwerks
description: Free Dimensional shows John O'Regan ready for his close-up, feeling like a sequel to 2010's Special Affections: more professional, calculated, and occasionally satisfying, but ultimately lacking the anything-goes magic that called for a sequel in the first place.

title: Young Hunger
label: Cascine
description: The debut LP from Jonquil frontman Hugo Manuel's Balearic pop project features guest vocal spots from Twin Shadow, Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs, Active Child, Glasser, El Perro Del Mar, and others.

title: Matricidal Sons of Bitches
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Fiery Furnace multi-instrumentalist's four-part opera about mother-killing sons is clearly the product of serious compositional intention, but at this stage of his career, Matthew Friedberger comes across like the Andy Kaufman of indie rock.

title: Honor Found In Decay
label: Neurot
description: Over the course of a 27-year career, the Oakland band has evolved from gritty metallic punk to harrowing post-hardcore prog to the majestic doom of their current phase. Their crushing, luminous new album is a highlight of the recent Neurosis discography.

title: Luxury Problems
label: Modern Love
description: Working with operatically trained vocalist Alison Skidmore, the Manchester producer has humanized his sound, made it more beautiful and richer on the surface while further accentuating its dark heart. The new dynamic leads to another big leap forward.

title: Animator
label: Dead Oceans
description: In the early stages of writing their third album, the Montreal art-pop band learned of a friend's death. The record they then put together, featuring string arrangements by members of Arcade Fire and Bell Orchestre, is suffused with grief, spiritual questioning, and the occasional haunting.

title: Connected
label: Kranky
description: Oren Ambarchi collaborated with fellow Australian musician, the artist Robin Fox, for this slow-build, mantra-like soundtrack to a contemporary dance piece. It's to the duo's credit that there's no sense of these pieces serving another purpose.

title: World Music
label: Stranded Rekords
description: The masked psychedelic band Goat claim their project stems from a long-running collective of townspeople in their small Swedish village: People have been playing under the name Goat in various incarnations for decades, but this nine-song, steady-burning World Music is the first proper release.

title: Cobra Juicy
label: Rad Cult
description: Balancing the grotesque and the beautiful, the Pittsburgh group's Kickstarter-funded new album may be their most accessible to date. But if this is psychedelia, it's only in the sense that each song replicates the intensity of the trip: the suicidal lows and the love-is-everything highs.

title: Banks
label: Matador
description: The Interpol frontman worked on Banks over the course of two years during free time on the road with his band. By dropping the Julian Plenti moniker and recording under his given name, the suggestion is that we're finally going to see some real, unfiltered Paul Banks.

title: Agnus Dei
label: Southern Lord
description: The Italian grind-infused hardcore band's fourth album is fast, furious, and hostile. Their black metal influences set them apart from the majority of their current Southern Lord labelmates, drawing a nifty little line between the past and present of Greg Anderson's roster.

title: Who Needs Who
label: Melodic
description: The Minneapolis chamber folk band's third album, Who Needs Who, was recorded after the break-up of Nona Marie Invie and Marshall LaCount. What ensues, in part, is a rebalancing of the two founding members' roles.

title: Little Sleepwalker
label: Audraglint
description: Grimes colleague Cecil Frena changed the name of his playful Gobble Gobble project after his former bandmates got busy with Purity Ring. His first official album as Born Gold doesn't have the populist ambitions of his peers, but it does show an intent to be taken seriously.

title: Lightning
label: Fader
description: The Brooklyn duo's fourth album marks a retreat from the slicked-up advances of 2010's Sidewalks, Lightning is a back-to-basics record.

title: Beyul
label: Profound Lore
description: After a decade of pitting denim-clad metal against strains of jazz and Middle Eastern atmospherics, the saxophone-weilding Chicago band Yakuza continue to forge a specialized and strange alloy on their latest album.

title: So Many Days
label: Aporia
description: Over a decade and a half into her solo career, Julie Doiron is still finding new feelings to reveal and new pathways by which to let the listener in. So Many Days has a genial air, but also contains some of the most harrowing material Doiron has written.

title: Halcyon
label: Polydor
description: Having scored a U.S. Top 10 hit, and performed at Prince William's wedding reception and Barack Obama's Christimas tree-lighting ceremony, the release of Ellie Goulding's second album, Halcyon, couldn't be timelier-- nor more varied a collection.

title: The Expanding Universe
label: Unseen Worlds
description: In 1977, electronic composer Laurie Spiegel's "Kepler's Harmony of the Worlds" traveled to the edge of the solar system as part of Voyager 1 and 2's "Golden Record". This reissue of her 1980 LP shows how Spiegel always contemplated orbits, heavenly bodies, and the cosmos through her compositions, while remaining affectionately human.

title: Local Business
label: XL
description: Flying the banner of punk, Titus Andronicus' third album sounds like something knocked out immediately by five guys in a room and captured on tape without the need for narration, a brass section, or multiple tempo changes.

title: I Begin
label: Indie
description: God Seed is the project of former Gorgoroth frontman Gaahl and bassist King ov Hell. Their debut features industrial deconstructions, ritualistic throbs, and nods to stoner metal and krautrock that position them outside the confines of traditional Norwegian black metal.

title: GEM
label: Fat Cat
description: As U.S. Girls, Meghan Remy makes haunted highway songs packed with eerily infectious hooks. Her newest record playfully appropriates the debauched excess of glam rock to achieve its own singular vibe.

title: Mars
label: DFA
description: Featuring guest spots from Twin Shadow and members of Yeasayer and Nomo, Mars finds Brooklyn-based, Sudanese-born multi-instrumentalist Ahmed Gallab working with Sudanese pop, Krautrock, 70s funk, free jazz, and global indie.

title: good kid, m.A.A.d city
label: Interscope
description: Kendrick Lamar's good kid, m.A.A.d city is fearless and brilliant, an unvarnished and nuanced peek into the rapper's inner life that ties straightforward rap thrills directly to its narrative.

title: Ornamented Walls
label: Modern Love
description: Dominick Fernow (Prurient, Cold Cave) releases eerie, dimly lit war-themed techno as Vatican Shadow. His debut for Manchester imprint Modern Love (Demdike Stare, Andy Stott) isn't an LP so much as a collection of material you may have missed and an addendum of tracks you don't want to miss.

title: Sunshine
label: Joyful Noise
description: The Brooklyn noise-rock duo of guitarist Sarah Register and drummer Andrya Ambro turn simple words and sounds into something larger on their relentless sophomore album.

title: Book Burner
label: Relapse
description: Book Burner is Pig Destroyer's fifth album, and despite a five-year gap since their last record and the addition of a new drummer, it's the work of a long-haul, tour-honed grindcore unit in frightening control of their caustic materials and even more caustic philosophy.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: In contrast to the streamlined, moody, and often muted dance-pop on last year's Blue Songs, Andy Butler's entry in the DJ-Kicks series pledges itself openly and unabashedly to debauched, dancefloor-centric house music.

title: The Haunted Man
label: Parlophone
description: Spacious, boldly orchestrated, and emotionally rich, Natasha Khan's latest is another step forward for the multi-instrumentalist and singer-songwriter. Featuring collaborations with Beck, Rob Ellis, David Sitek, Portishead's Adrian Utley, and others, The Haunted Man is at once striking and enigmatic.

title: Autumn Bird Songs
label: Graveface
description: The Songs:Ohia/Magnolia Electric Co. frontman made these stark recordings before health problems led to financial problems and before he started working on a farm. The mini-album accompanies a book that includes art by William Schaff and writing by Will Sheff, John Darnielle, and Darren Jackson.

title: Ghost EP
label: Capitol
description: Sky Ferreira's new EP veers from effervescent synth pop to sleepy acoustic ballads and features songwriting and production collaborations with Shirley Manson, Cass McCombs, Jon Brion, and Dev Hynes.

title: Zodiac EP
label: Vase
description: The 23-year-old Canadian producer Jeremy Rose first gained notice for his alleged production work for the Weeknd. With that in mind, it's hard not to compare his 5-song EP for fellow Canadian beat maker Jacques Greene's Vase label to the Weeknd's House of Balloons.

title: The Feeling
label: Captured Tracks
description: Naomi Punk's proper debut, originally released on vinyl and now being issued by Captured Tracks digitally and on CD, captures the Olympia, Wash., trio studying the grunge rulebook just to tear it in half.

title: Dept. of Disappearance
label: Anti-
description: The second solo album from former Grandaddy frontman Jason Lytle begins much like his first, with a veiled statement about the state of his career, and ends with the kind of mock-epic album closer he does so well. But in between, Dept. contains frequently bracing explorations of the unexpected.

title: Rework: Philip Glass Remixed
label: Kora
description: This 2xCD Beck-helmed remix collection features reworkings of Philip Glass by Tyondai Braxton, Dan Deacon, Cornelius, Pantha du Prince, Amon Tobin, Nosaj Thing, Jóhann Jóhannsson, and Beck himself, among others.

title: Untogether
label: Rallye
description: This L.A.-via-Austin dream-pop outfit's second album comes fully stocked with the sort of minimal, richly melodic New Order-esque guitar patterns and strobe-lit flashbacks that make for pure indie pop catnip.

title: Unknown Rooms: A Collection of Acoustic Songs
label: Sargent House
description: On her the acoustic Unknown Rooms, Los Angeles musician Chelsea Wolfe attempts to reconnect with her folk roots, allowing a few sunrays to poke into the gothic sepulchre she built on 2011's Apokalypsis. But this isn't exactly her campfire record.

title: Tragicomedies
label: Planet Mu
description: Glaswegian vocalist and multi-instrumentalist Rudi Zygadlo's second album runs the gamut of emotion from poignancy to parody, often within the same song. On Tragicomedies, he moves beyond his dubstep beginnings, stretching mainstream ideas of melody.

title: Information Retrieved
label: Temporary Residence
description: Pinback keeps its own internal pace, independent of all outside noise occurring in the typically long gaps between their full-lengths. Despite being five years in the making, their latest LP finds them as consistent as ever.

title: System Preferences
label: The Ship
description: Earlimart's seventh LP, the Los Angeles indie rock duo's first in four years, is another in what's becoming a long line of sumptuously arranged, immaculately written, laudably restrained LPs. System Preferences gets most of its flaws from Earlimart's pursuit of flawlessness.

title: Stunt Rhythms
label: Big Dada
description: Amon Tobin disguises himself as Two Fingers for his latest boundary-pushing release-- though in this case, the Brazilian producer is tinkering around in the realm of Americanized dubstep. Seems like the brainy, meticulous knob-twiddler is having a laugh at the expense of his reputation.

title: Tender New Signs
label: Mexican Summer
description: Tamaryn's sophomore album finds the Calif. duo still steeped in their own personal brand of shoegaze, but they've stripped away the layers of their debut, revealing a deeper vulnerability.

title: Daughter of Cloud
label: Polyvinyl
description: At its best, the rarities set Daughter of Cloud is a reminder of how good Kevin Barnes can be when he imposes discipline on his talent for groove-heavy psych-rock. Unfortunately, Daughter also has plenty of examples of what happened to Of Montreal's music once he grew bored with discipline.

title: Jiaolong
label: Jiaolong
description: This collection of dance tracks produced by Caribou's Dan Snaith under his Daphni alias is the excitable product of an artist who could no longer watch a scene from the sidelines. A sense of abandon and exploration keeps Jiaolong from sounding like the work of a dilettante.

title: Ralph Lauren Reefa
label: self-released
description: Young Dro is a humbly astonishing rapper. The DJ Burn One-curated Ralph Lauren Reefa is one of the Atlanta MC's strongest tapes in a while, showing him at his lyrical, funny, vivid, local-hero best.

title: The Ganzfeld EP
label: Thrill Jockey
description: For The Ganzfeld EP, Drew Daniel and M.C. Schmidt conducted experiments on volunteers, blasting them with white noise while attempting to beam the concept of the record into their minds. The test subjects' interpretations of the concept make up this EP, which draws a sharp outline around the unfamiliar.

title: Allelujah! Don't Bend! Ascend!
label: Constellation
description: Two weeks ago came the surprise announcement of a new album by Godspeed You! Black Emperor, their first in 10 years. If they felt like a band of the moment around the turn of the millennium, now, in a time of rapid cultural turnover and bite-sized music consumption, Godspeed feel out of step in a very necessary way.

title: No Can Do
label: Triple Crown
description: Where previous Ladyhawk albums sprawled with extended guitar solos and more-than-the-sum-of-their-parts sloppy chemistry, the Vancouver band's third full length skews closer to lean power pop than it does rambling classic rock.

title: I Love Grime
label: Rinse
description: Rinse FM, a longtime UK pirate turned licensed community station, is in the midst of its 18th birthday celebration. Their I Love Grime compilation features discs curated by current Rinse fixtures, the grime scene veteran Spyro and Sian Anderson, a rare female grime DJ.

title: Ye Are Gods
label: Ajna Offensive
description: Basing their psychedelic hymns on the Process Church, the 60s/70s cult that worshipped the union of God and Satan, Sabbath Assembly's second album features a new vocalist, Jamie Myers (Wolves in the Throne Room), and guest narration by Genesis P-Orridge.

title: Numbers
label: Odd Future
description: The duo of  OFWGKTA members Hodgy Beats and Left Brain burrow deeper into their own world on their sophomore album, a collection that raises the question: What's the end game for MellowHype?

title: All We Love We Leave Behind
label: Epitaph
description: The Boston hardcore band Converge are nearing the 25-year mark, though you might not guess it from the manic energy crammed into it their excellent eighth album, All We Love We Leave Behind. If you go beyond the amped, break-neck intensity and listen to the compositions, it becomes clearer: You don't just show up and write songs like this.

title: The Killer
label: 50 Weapons
description: German techno producer René Pawlowitz releases his least praiseworthy but most fun album to date. The Killer's anti-editorialising recalls Carl Craig's mid-90s stretch: those massive mid-range synth tremors, the lumbering yet quirky rhythms, the sense of vinyl warmth that infuses even the most glacial passages.

title: Colored Emotions
label: Domino
description: The electrified Minneapolis psych-country trio Night Moves originally posted their debut album for free on Bandcamp. They've since signed with Domino and have given the record a facelift with the help of producer Thom Monahan (Vetiver, Beachwood Sparks).

title: Commercial Music
label: Chapter Music
description: On the Australian duo's third record of encircling, weighty drones, Jarrod Zlatic and Nisa Venerosa continue their slow evolutionary crawl: There's a taut new robustness to their sound, their first proper song titles-- and even nods to where they could end up in the future.

title: Accelerator
label: Drag City
description: The final album in Royal Trux's deal with Virgin Records, a record Virgin didn't put out, is the most openly celebratory yet perversely strange entry in the dirtbag-rock duo's canon. Accelerator sounds every bit as absurd, chaotic, and exhilarating as it did 14 years ago.

label: Odd Future
description: The Sacramento hardcore band's new LP is a comparatively hefty release for Trash Talk, and it's their first outing on Odd Future Records. Their way with brief brutality has fallen away too, in favor of mountainous, pile-driving riffs.

title: Elemental Themes
label: Stones Throw
description: New York analog synth freak Morgan Z's debut album, one of the last mastered by Nilesh Patel (Björk, Daft Punk), is essentially the score to your favorite "Mystery Science Theatre 3000" episode, only this time, the commentary is up to you.

title: Rinse Presents: Royal-T
label: Rinse
description: On his debut album for Rinse FM's in-house label, the young British producer Mark Taylor offers an all-embracing vision of rudely extroverted modern garage, unified by his familiar palette of turgid bass tones, decaying synth riffs, and shuddering, syncopated beats.

title: Cokefloat!
label: Fat Cat
description: The Glaswegian trio's debut is alternately thrilling and mildly embarrassing for being the sum of its 90s influences, but the lyrical presentation of the band as flawed and multifaceted makes Cokefloat*!* stand out despite doing nothing new musically.

title: Shut Down the Streets
label: Matador
description: On Shut Down the Streets, the New Pornographers' Carl Newman is writing autobiographical songs for the first time, about the birth of his son and the death of his mother. Though for the most part, the most heartfelt, eloquent statements here are expressed musically.

title: Metz
label: Sub Pop
description: The post-hardcore sludge-punk trio Metz have spent the last five years becoming the most brutalizing band in Toronto. For their debut, they've distilled their set-list standards into 29 minutes of pure but artfully rendered chaos.

title: Assimilating the Shadow
label: Digitalis
description: The Boston-based, Brazil-born Ricardo Donoso eschews percussion to create rhythm through timing and momentum. His second album takes roots in dance and techno as well as the minimalism of Terry Riley, Cluster's trance, and Oneohtrix Point Never's spaced-out arpeggios.

title: Embers and Revelations
label: Relapse
description: Led by Bangladesh-born vocalist/guitarist Vetis Monarch, the Canadian black/death metal band's third album, their first for Relapse, revels in Satanic majesty, sensuous filth, and an atmosphere that mixes Eastern sounds with elements more typical of extreme metal.

title: Lonesome Dreams
label: IAMSOUND
description: Ben Schneider's debut LP finds the Michigan-to-L.A. transplant shedding much of the electronic flourishes and international flavors of his early EPs in favor of harmony-rich folk-rock.

title: Mumps, etc.
label: Anticon
description: Whether the result of taking an unusually long time off between records or not, on WHY?'s fourth album, Yoni Wolf has sunk even further into himself, but not to discover some sort of deeper truth about the human condition. Mumps, etc. is an often unlistenably solipsistic, lazy album from a band that was often excellent.

title: Twins
label: Drag City
description: Twins is Segall's third LP of 2012, and stands at a crossroads somewhere between all his records to date. There are ballads, searing garage punk, sentimental love songs, two-minute bursts rubbing up next to longer cuts; all executed with faster tempos, thicker fuzz, and more power. Twins makes a great case for naming Segall as San Francisco's garage laureate.

title: Maserati VII
label: Temporary Residence
description: VII pursues no radical new directions for Maserati, but even though you sort of already know these songs, they still have enough engaging motion and kinetic force that if you ever loved them in the first place, you'll love them all over again here.

title: First of a Living Breed
label: Stones Throw
description: Dropping knowledge is good. Pedantry, lecturing listeners and telling them what to think is bad. Those poles make up two sides bisected by a thin line, which Homeboy Sandman straddles for the entirety of his first LP with Stones Throw.

title: Shifty Adventures in Nookie Wood
label: Double Six
description: John Cale's new studio album, featuring some work from Danger Mouse, is definitely strange. But the album's lacquered surface coats the chaos and imposes unwelcome order.

title: Lonerism
label: Modular
description: Tame Impala's second full-length, Lonerism, will once again be compared to albums from the late 1960s and early 70s. But the project is exciting because, by maximizing the use of the available technology, it taps into the progressive and experimental spirit of psychedelic rock, and not just the sound.

title: Formerly Extinct
label: Drag City
description: The second album from guitarists Sir Richard Bishop (Sun City Girls) and Ben Chasny (Six Organs of Admittance) and drummer Chris Corsano confirms Rangda to be an active, cohesive band of the highest caliber.

title: Music Is Painting in the Air
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The RVNG label compiled this collection from five Sensations' Fix albums, one Franco Falsini solo record, and a series of unreleased outtakes. This work embraces a range of styles, including prog, kosmische musik, trad-rock, ambient, and psychedelia.

title: Other Worlds
label: Secretly Canadian
description: For the follow-up to Victoria Bergsman's 2009 LP, East of Eden, recorded in Pakistan, the former Concretes frontwoman traveled to Hawaii with the Tough Alliance's Henning Fürst. The result sounds like a vacation from a vacation, unwound, lightly dubby, and bearing the glow of new love.

title: NO LOVE DEEP WEB
label: self-released
description: The 13 tracks on NO LOVE DEEP WEB thrive on paranoia and aggression, feelings threaded together by the sense that everything could be ending right now. For the second time this year, Death Grips have released a record that's both ruthless and rewarding.

title: Falling
label: Hardly Art
description: The Seattle-based band's home-recorded sophomore effort adds some additional polish to their specific kind of yearning, autumn-sunset guitar-pop.

title: Space Zone
label: Planet Mu
description: Space Zone is the debut album from 18-year-old David Davis, a Chicago-based producer inextricably tied to his hometown's faster-than-fast and repetitive genre of footwork. While he's still grounded in the genre, his best moments here find him exploring outside its boundaries.

title: Alight in Ashes
label: Profound Lore
description: Menace Ruine first emerged with links to several cadres of bands, from black metal or new age to power electronics or astral folk. On their latest, they retain qualities of all those realms, whether in black metal's obsessive saturation or Geneviève Beaulieu's voice.

title: Baby Face Killa
label: self-released
description: With his new mixtape Freddie Gibbs has perfected the gangsta formula he's been honing for the last few years. Baby Face Killa features spots from Spaceghostpurrp, Curren$y, and others along with a strong selection of beats.

title: Kaleidoscope Dream
label: RCA
description: Following on this three Art Dealer Chic EPs, the young Los Angeles-based R&B singer and songwriter has come into his own. Kaleidoscope Dream is a gem of an album, respectful of tradition, quietly ambitious, and deeply personal.

title: Circles
label: Sacred Bones
description: On their Ralph Waldo Emerson-referencing latest album, Wooden Shjips guitarist Erik "Ripley" Johnson and keyboardist Sanae Yamada seem anxious to bolster their sound while still remaining sinister, groovy, and far-and-fuzzed-out.

title: Soft Fall
label: Dead Oceans
description: Spend a little time with this Philadelphia psych-tinged synth-pop band's sophomore album and the pretty textures fall back, revealing a smart, sneakily ambitious pop record. These are big-stage songs couched in bedroom-spangle production.

title: Sugaring Season
label: Anti-
description: Beth Orton’s sixth full-length album, her first since 2006, finds her more at ease with the tag of singer-songwriter than ever before. There are no unexpected detours or tangents, just 10 songs delivered by a voice of seemingly effortless expression.

title: Ultraísta
label: Temporary Residence
description: Producer Nigel Godrich steps out with a new band, working with Los Angeles-based producer/drummer Joey Waronker (who also does time with Godrich in Thom Yorke's Atoms for Peace) and Dimbleby & Capper vocalist Laura Bettinson. The trio's self-titled debut is a collection of dark, krautrock-indebted synth pop.

title: FEAT
label: Decon
description: For their first album of original productions, the second-wave drag-and-drop duo ropes in over 20 collaborators, including Class Actress, A.C. Newman, Hooray For Earth, Kleenex Girl Wonder, and Cadence Weapon.

title: Play...
label: Memphis Industries
description: Field Music Play… pulls together covers of songs by Syd Barrett, Pet Shop Boys, Leonard Cohen, Roxy Music, the Beatles, and others. Musically and curatorially, it showcases the duo as pragmatists with an impossibly dry sense of humor.

title: The 2nd Law
label: Warner Bros.
description: Muse frontman Matt Bellamy jokingly described his band's sixth studio album as a "christian gangsta rap jazz odyssey, with some ambient rebellious dubstep and face melting metal flamenco cowboy psychedelia." If only.

title: Transcendental Youth
label: Merge
description: As they hide out from the cops, root through garbage, peer paranoid through the blinds, and dig their nails into their hands just for something to do, the protagonists on the Mountain Goats newest are linked not by place or time but by a particular spiritual stance. And a horn section.

title: Heavy Mood
label: Team Love
description: Like a glittery, tap-dancing unicorn, Tilly and the Wall have spent the better part of a decade giving meaning to the phrase "twee as fuck." On their first album in four years, the Omaha indie poppers come out swinging.

title: Sundark and Riverlight
label: Essential
description: Patrick Wolf's 10th-anniversary collection is a double album containing new acoustic versions of previously released songs. It isn't quite a greatest-hits compilation, though it's mostly singles and fan favorites.

title: Until the Quiet Comes
label: Warp
description: Following the maximalism of 2010's landmark Cosmogramma, Steven Ellison returns with a comparatively subtle and focused album. Quiet re-thinks his music's relationship to space and mood with a new and welcome sense of simplicity.

title: Architecture of Loss
label: Bedroom Community
description: The third album by Icelandic composer, Björk producer, and Bedroom Community founder Valgeir Sigurðsson is a score for a Stephen Petronio ballet that pits emotive chamber music (including piano from Nico Muhly) against furtive electronic frequencies.

title: Look a Little Closer
label: Lefse
description: The multi-instrumentalist and vocalist David Levesque has described his sound as "Mickey Mouse tribal." On his debut Levek LP, he applies his exquisite fingerpicking and feathery wisp of a voice to folk tapestries and light funk.

title: An Awesome Wave
label: Canvasback
description: Alt-J's debut album went Top 20 in the UK, and they're favorites to win November's Mercury Music Prize. The Cambridge-based pop band's been described as "the new Radiohead," but that tag ultimately says more about lowered standards.

title: 777: Cosmosophy
label: Debemur Morti
description: The black metal project of French multi-instrumentalist Vindsval uses torrents of drums and sheets of tremolo guitars as starting points for industrial, gothic, noisy, liturgical, and murky rock'n'roll excursions. Cosmosophy is the near-perfect final installment in the three-album, two-hour 777 trilogy Blut Aus Nord's released over the last 18 months.

title: YOKOKIMTHURSTON
label: Chimera
description: The most surprising thing about YOKOKIMTHURSTON is that it took until 2012 to happen. After all, what are Sonic Youth if not the modern manifestation of the avant/rock ideal that Yoko and her late husband John Lennon forged with Plastic Ono Band?

title: Deer Creek Canyon
label: Sub Pop
description: The singer-songwriter, who was part of both Seattle's Carissa's Wierd and its spin-off, Band of Horses, comes into her own on her third record for Sub Pop. Her voice is stronger on this album, richer, more sure of itself through practice or sheer will.

title: Sundowning
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: This punk band from Vancouver has learned a thing or two about sludge and volume from the year punk broke, but Nü Sensae also have the finesse to break the mold. At its best, the record is a thrilling example of the power of righteous anger.

title: State Hospital EP
label: Canvasback / Atlantic
description: The Glaswegian band recently signed to Atlantic, and the State Hospital EP seems a strange experiment in this context. It's never too far from what you might expect from them, yet often comes off as unnecessarily simplified.

title: Food & Liquor II: The Great American Rap Album Pt. 1
label: Atlantic
description: Lupe Fiasco doesn't give you anything straight: Not a verse, a simile, or a song, and certainly not an album. As an artist, he's helplessly drawn towards perversity. His latest is his most relaxed, rewarding effort in a while. At its best, it feels like a re-introduction to a promising artist who spent some time in the wilderness.

title: Overgrown Path
label: Captured Tracks
description: Once a player with acts such as Ariel Pink's Haunted Graffiti, Cass McCombs, and Deerhoof, Chris Cohen's solo debut is pleasingly blurry on where and when it's supposed to feel beamed from, an effect aided by his cracked, spidery guitars, grand pianos, and Ray Davies croon.

title: Music For Reliquary House / In 1980 I Was a Blue Square
label: NNA Tapes
description: Oneohtrix's side of this split is coarse and challenging, a serrated edge severed into a once-placid template-- a thread picked up by Hell on his half of the record, which begins in conflict and ends in a form of serene resolution.

title: Salute Me or Shoot Me 4: Banned From America
label: self-released
description: Waka's energy has an almost gravitational pull and it's as strong here as ever.  There's a gleeful streak running through Salute Me 4 that gives it a decidedly different vibe: It's an hour of shouting that sounds like a hug.

title: Oblivion Hunter EP
label: Load
description: Lightning Bolt's latest gathers unreleased material recorded in 2008; though positioned as an EP, it's actually an album-length collection that serves as a solid summary of what they do well.

title: Motor Nighttime World 3
label: Music Man
description: Motor Nighttime World 3 is less funky than Hood's earlier, revered works, but it relies on the same blueprints: spartan rhythmic patterns, no fat, no showboating. Big and contemplative, Motor is based on the cautionary tale of Detroit, but it can't help but find some beauty in the wreckage.

title: Tempest
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Produced by Optimo's JD Twitch and featuring members of Liquid Liquid, Tempest is an oasis of carefully deployed glitz after the desert-like emptiness of some of the San Francisco dance band's past records.

title: Elysium
label: Astralwerks
description: For Pet Shop Boys' first decade, they were impostors so studious and inspired that they were better than the real thing. Now they've settled into being elder statesmen of pop at a time when pop has little use for elder statesmen, and they're off-puttingly bitter about it.

title: Document
label: Capitol
description: If 1985's Fables of the Reconstruction was R.E.M.'s most self-consciously Southern record to date and 1986's Lifes Rich Pageant their most overtly political, Document maintained both their regional self-definition as well as their indirect social engagement.

title: Strapped
label: Mexican Summer
description: Two years in the making, the Los Angeles post-punk band's self-produced sophomore LP finds them following the course of their debut with a few experimental turns like horns, synth squiggles, and wah-wah flourishes.

title: RIITIIR
label: Nuclear Blast
description: The Norwegian metal giants' latest album, the longest album of Enslaved's career, attempts to spotlight all of the band's parts in one package. In the discussion leading up to its release, its greatness has felt like a foregone conclusion.

title: Mala in Cuba
label: Brownswood
description: On his first proper LP*,* the dubstep pioneer set himself to an ambitious task. Challenged by musical sage Gilles Peterson to mix soundsystem culture with the traditional melodies and instruments of Cuban music, Mala traveled to Havana to retrieve those sounds from their source.

title: End of Daze EP
label: Sub Pop
description: The Dum Dum Girls have transcended their influences but more importantly they've stuck around, pushed past their limits, and gotten better with each release. End of Daze is the best thing they've done, succinct but irrefutable proof that this band's dynamite has a long fuse.

title: Function Falls
label: Brassland
description: This four-song EP came about when Radiolab asked the self-sufficient Hudson, NY, duo to cover New Order's "Blue Monday" for a compilation, which led Buke and Gase into trying to write a song a day for a week.

title: Piramida
label: 4AD
description: Efterklang's new album, which takes its name from an Arctic Circle ghost town to which the Danish band traveled in 2011 to gather field recordings, features a guest violinist, pianist, and a 70-piece girls' choir.

title: Incorruptible Heart
label: Paracadute
description: On Lavender Diamond's long-time-coming second album, Becky Stark is still preoccupied with love, but makes use of a brighter, sexier, spacier palette to explore a favored theme.

title: Somethin 'Bout Kreay
label: Columbia
description: A year on from the breakout YouTube single "Gucci Gucci", Kreayshawn returns with her major label debut. It would be difficult to argue that Somethin' Bout Kreay is a waste of Kreayshawn's talent, because talent has been something of a non-factor in her story.

title: I Bet on Sky
label: Jagjaguwar
description: If you were a Dinosaur Jr. fan the first time around, it still seems amazing, three albums into their post-2005 reunion run, they're together at all. But at this point, the early drama isn't as interesting as the fact that the new albums-- 2007's Beyond, 2009's Farm, and now I Bet on Sky-- are all good to very good.

title: The Threnody of Triumph
label: Candlelight
description: The British black metal band's darkly romantic third album incorporates heathen accents and condensed post-rock melodies and runs it all through a decidedly English filter.

title: The Sound of The Life of The Mind
label: ImaVeePee Records / Sony
description: Post-a cappella self-tribute album, post-"The Sing-Off" judging gig, post-diminishing-returns solo career, Ben Folds Five's first album in 13 years feels obligatory and uninspired.

title: Meat and Bone
label: Boombox / Mom + Pop
description: On their first album of original material since 2004, the Blues Explosion never assume their comeback is assured. They're reapplying for the job of America's most raucous, hardest-working rock'n'roll band, and will let the sweat speak for itself.

title: Kin
label: Cooperative
description: A couple of years after a mysterious rollout, the Swedish duo of vocalist Jonna Lee and producer Claes Björklund released their debut LP, an audiovisual project with an accompanying DVD. It takes a little calibration to listen to Kin as a proper album, but it's doable.

title: Total Loss
label: Acéphale / Weird World
description: Tom Krell's intimate second How to Dress Well album uses the common tools of R&B and pop expression-- four-minute songs, autobiography, choruses, confession-- to create a work of poignant and devastating art.

title: Sic Alps
label: Drag City
description: For their fourth album proper, Sic Alps headed into a real studio-- though it's not reduced the essential strangeness of their music. Where Sic Alps were once wasted and wobbly, they're now stoned and serene.

title: Look to the Sky
label: The End
description: Fourteen years after his solo debut, the former Smashing Pumpkins guitarist releases a followup album that sounds like it, too, was recorded in 1998.

title: Mourning in America and Dreaming in Color
label: Rhymesayers/Warner
description: Mourning in America and Dreaming in Color is where the political agitation of The Undisputed Truth and the social humanism of Us intersect, and there's no vague platitudes or defeatist cynicism here. Ali is a man with a purpose and zero interest in holding back.

title: Breakthrough
label: Brainfeeder
description: It's taken nearly a decade for L.A.'s Gaslamp Killer to release his debut album, though he's hardly been slacking in the interim. Breakthrough summarizes his recent creative mode pretty definitively, manifesting in a high-quality dose of doom-struck instrumental hip-hop.

title: Mirage Rock
label: Columbia
description: Band of Horses' fourth album moves further into the realm of radio-conscious pop staked out by its 2010 predecessor, Infinite Arms. Befitting its name, Mirage Rock is so lightweight and inconsequential that it truly does seem more like an illusion than a record.

title: Effigies of Evil
label: Relapse
description: The Finnish doom metal group has always cited the horror aesthetic as one of its greatest influences, but on its debut album for Relapse Records, it reads as shlocky rather than invoking any genuine air of fear.

title: Runner
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Sea and Cake occupy an indie rock niche all their own. Their 10th album is one of their most subtly varied, and it can be an immersive listening experience if you give yourself over to it.

title: Bend Beyond
label: Woodsist
description: The Brooklyn band's seventh album features more disciplined songwriting, and the production offers more clarity and variety than ever before. While 2011's Sun and Shade exhibited Woods' jammy side amid the usual folk-pop gems, Bend Beyond is all pop, all the time.

title: Algiers
label: Anti-
description: The Tucson duo traveled to New Orleans to record its latest album, named for a neighborhood on the southwest banks of the Mississippi River, home to krewe dens, Catholic churches, jazz clubs, and Katrina-flooded homes.

title: Ascent
label: Drag City
description: The core of Comets on Fire are all present on Ascent, and together they help old bandmate Ben Chasny pummel some new tracks and reconfigure several from his vast back catalog.

title: The Inner Treaty
label: Drag City / Sun Ark
description: Sun Araw's last two albums were musical approximations of pitch blackness. The Inner Treaty focuses on a lighter, more scattered sound, a sound rooted in gospel and the positive, mystical explorations of jazz artists like Pharoah Sanders and Alice Coltrane.

title: Kill My Blues
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Kill My Blues, the Corin Tucker Band's sophomore album, is being heralded as the former Sleater-Kinney bandleader's return to riot grrrl form. But she's now a grown-azz, 39-year-old woman tackling topics that weren't on her radar at 20.

title: Shields
label: Warp
description: Shields is Grizzly Bear's most compositionally adventurous record. Though full of baroque, detail-rich production and latticework melodies, it also offers an emotionally resonant core. The album is an excavation of loneliness, melancholy, and self-reliance.

title: Score: The Complete Sextet Works 2002-2007
label: Northern Spy
description: Bringing the sheet-music rigor of classical to avant-prog, Zs carved out a distinct mark at the end of the sonic alphabet. This 4xCD set collects the NYC band's work as a sextet in the mid 2000s, complete with bonus tracks and live recordings.

title: No Absolutes in Human Suffering
label: Black Market Activities
description: On the Salt Lake City, Utah, grindcore band's third and best album, the sounds are as intensely amped as vocalist Jon Parkin's colorful, politically charged lyrics.

title: Palindrome Hunches
label: Brushfire
description: The Slowdive and Mojave 3 vocalist/guitarist's third solo album feels like a hushed, close-gathered singalong. At this point, he's not about reinvention so much as he is exploring possibilities from a central starting place.

title: Held
label: Tri Angle
description: Manchester-born producer Holy Other's debut full-length builds on the bedroom territory of his previous EP With U to reveal a bigger, messier story. Held is a wholly sensual, painfully physical modern love album.

title: Butter
label: Serpents and Snakes
description: On their third album, Turbo Fruits offer ripping guitars and barroom aggression in service of throwback rock'n'roll. Working with producer Jim Eno, the former Be Your Own Pet members offer a carefully honed caricature of themselves, complete with tales of bar fights, gambling, hitting the road, drinking, and smoking weed.

title: Fantasm Planes
label: Warp
description: The longtime Warp signee returns with an EP that mirrors his restless nature. It moves from  jazzy lightness reminiscent of the electro-fusion of Red Snapper to moody trip-hop on a track that features Martina Topley-Bird.

title: Field Report
label: Partisan
description: Chris Porterfield, the onetime bandmate of Justin Vernon and Megafaun in DeYarmond Edison, recorded his debut solo collection of lyrical folk rock at Vernon's April Base studios.

title: Moms
label: Barsuk
description: After 2010's Mines, Brent Knopf left the band and Danny Seim and Justin Harris continued as a duo. Their first record as a twosome, Moms is without doubt the most aggressive record Menomena have ever made.

title: Tempest
label: Columbia
description: For all its detours toward sadness and alienation, death is the real story on Bob Dylan's latest album, very much a record about The End. He's learned, at 71, that death doesn't necessarily come with a lesson, that sometimes it just comes.

title: The Predicting Machine
label: Kompakt
description: On his second release for Kompakt in as many years, the Austrian-born, California-based electronic producer pulls his sounds from a deep catalog of eras, labels, and styles. It's a record that feels as open to the past as it is to the future.

title: Observator
label: Vice
description: The Raveonettes have always had a promiscuous relationship with pop history, dredging grungy 1950s juvie rock and 60s girl groups through 70s punk and 90s shoegaze. A decade into its career, the band seems to be settling comfortably into itself, which is good and bad.

title: Half Way Home
label: Bathetic
description: The Missouri-born Chicago psych folk musician and Will Oldham collaborator's magnificent second album is powered by her extraordinary voice, elegant strokes of wordplay, and a thoughtful, never morbid belief in the finality of death.

title: Putrifiers II
label: In the Red
description: With their reputation as one of America's most formidable live acts wholly assured, Thee Oh Sees explore the possibilities of the studio and more lustrous modes of psychedelia on Putrifiers II. It's a convenient gateway into the garage rock vets' dense discography.

title: Bootlegs
label: Mona
description: For an artist with a tendency to sound too slick, too clever by half, and too consummate, Lerche's raw-feeling live album finds him sounding unguarded and loose; it's like watching your uptight friend get shitfaced.

title: Negotiations
label: Sub Pop
description: The longstanding Portland duo is in the midst of an impressive second act. The Helio Sequence's fifth LP, like its 2008 predecessor, is a big record, its towering choruses and wide-open spaces making for plenty of high drama.

title: Love Will Prevail
label: Sacred Bones
description: Sean Ragon, former Love as Laughter bassist and now a Brooklyn record store owner, expands his post-punk folk sound on this second proper full-band album. Here, he transforms Cult of Youth from one man's caustic catharsis into something increasingly inviting and alluring.

title: Love This Giant
label: 4AD / Todo Mundo
description: This collaboration between David Byrne and St. Vincent's Annie Clark is largely concerned with human transformation. On the surface, these two have quite a few commonalities, but collaborations aren't always as simple as pairing two smart artists cut from the same cloth.

title: Come of Age
label: Sony
description: On their second album, the Vaccines have created a record about a rock band treating their job with the checked out disinterest of an office drone, doing the bare minimum to get by, learning nothing, and being scared to death by the obligations that come with appearing to give a shit.

title: The Carpenter
label: American
description: The once bare-boned, focused band releases its second album on Rick Rubin's American label, an at-times bloated collection of meditations on aging and death.

title: For My Parents
label: Temporary Residence
description: The Japanese post-rock band's latest features backing strings from the Wordless Music Orchestra and the maximalist production of Henry Hirsch (Michael Jackson, Madonna, Lenny Kravitz).

title: Coexist
label: Young Turks
description: The London trio follows its now-classic 2009 debut with an album that's even more stripped down and minimal. Coexist takes the most distinctive things about the xx and eliminates virtually everything else.

title: Sentielle Objectif Actualite
label: Editions Mego
description: As one half of experimental duo SND, and more so under his own name, Mark Fell conducts unapologetic beat experiments. His newest solo effort is a study in deprivation, a reminder that psychedelic experiences can occur while totally sober if you deny yourself food or rest.

title: Tracer
label: True Panther
description: On their second LP,  Teengirl Fantasy experiment with guest vocalists including Panda Bear, Kelela, and Laurel Halo. But their best moments come when they showcase their ear for rich and tactile instrumentals.

title: Heat Lightning Rumbles in the Distance
label: ATO
description: The Drive-By Truckers co-founder's new solo album was inspired by the bleakest part of his personal history. The songs here survey lives marked by alcoholism, loneliness, loss of loved ones, and lessons learned the hard way.

title: I Know What Love Isn't
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Because its 10 songs are variations on the single theme of "heartbreak," Jens Leman has said I Know What Love Isn't feels like the first proper album he's made.

title: In Limbo
label: Carpark
description: Formed by Kristina Lieberson, keyboardist for Here We Go Magic, TEEN make cloudy, lo-fi indie that wouldn't sound out of character being banged out in a suburban basement.

title: Feed Me Diamonds
label: Ultra
description: Two years after her debut EP, MNDR's Amanda Warner returns with a Marina Abramović-referencing electro-pop LP she's called an attempt to "[challenge] money, wealth, power and the class system."

title: Silver Age
label: Merge
description: Following 2009's stately Life and Times, Bob Mould's latest solo album is so true to fuzz-pop form you might mistake it for an unearthed bonus disc of quality Sugar outtakes. It arrives as a totem of his continued influence on today's mainstream and indie-level artists alike.

title: Ocean Roar
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Ocean Roar is the second of a pair of albums Phil Elverum recorded on extended break from tour. May's Clear Moon was a dreamy fantasia about home.
